Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2011 12:22PM elmcity69 wrote: I'm so sorry about your friend, Pure. I always hated using the phrase "it sucks", but boy, nothing else quite cuts it, does it? I have done the whole roller coaster countless times - sad to mad to despair to hope. I feel sometimes as if I'm stuck in some Stephen King novella - Cancerland! the amusement park no one wants to visit. Anyway, at this point, I am so determined to keep cancer from taking another thing --ie, my hope and zest-- that I "power past" the fears of recurrence. They exist, and I have moments when I picture my funeral orÂ  the things I would do if it happens, but for the most part, I try to focus on the fact that worry doesn't prevent it, and I want to live life to the fullest BECAUSE of that. Not easy, and I"m not sermonizing or trying to gatekeep anyone else's feelings. Some days are harder than others - just today, I was finishing up yoga class in shivasana (resting pose) and tears were streaming down my cheeks because, well, because. prayers and (((hugs))) to you. glad we can hash this out all together. janyce

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 08:18PM elmcity69 wrote: I have the BRCA2 gene. My mother died at 59 from BC, her younger sister at 44yo, and another sister had it at 60 and survived. I had an oophorectomy last October; the surgery itself was easy, and I've had limited hot flashes. I'm 41, however, and already have two children, so the fertility issue was nonexistent. Yes, the sad reality is, the damn gene exponentially raises the risk. Maybe sitting with a genetics counselor and mapping out the pros and cons...my cousin is 30, has the gene also, and is taking her ovaries out @40yo, no matter what (and is pregnant, happily). I'm only citing her story to illustrate how every woman is different, with different priorities. Good luck to you. Feel free to PM me about the ooph if you want - Â Janyce

Posts.Content: elmcity69 wrote: Whew - have I learned perspective today. Was feeling sorry for myself, planning my own funeral - cried last night when my, husband started innocently talking about beefing up the retirement accounts. Sometimes, I feel like cancer has taken over the world - or at least my world. It's like a perverse take on the Brady Bunch (Jan crying, "It's always Marcia, Marcia, Marcia!" cancer cancer cancer) Anyway, my dear friend's 13yo niece died this afternoon. She was born with a cardiac defect -reversal of ventricles-- and it was known from the start she would need this (supposedly) life saving operation. 20 hours last week in a Boston hospital, top surgeon..and then, started declining over the last few days. One of the worst parts? my dear friend, her husband, and 12 yo daughter (who spent 3 weeks at sailing camp with this 13yo girl, her cousin) are in Ireland and no one has been able to reach them. I'm sorry to ramble, but I just wanted to share my wake up call. I mean, cancer is still crazy, unjust, and scary. I definitely want to live to see my children grow up - and I plan to. But today reminded me there are other tragedies in the world. and while I'm at it: if you're the praying kind, or karma kind, or energy kind - this girl's family needs it all by the truckload. xo J Dx 9/24/2009, ILC, 2cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 15/19 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 12:31PM elmcity69 wrote: PTSD is my middle name, I think, and I can't imagine how most survivors don't have it, in varying degrees. Somedays, I cry without "reason" - hearing a song my son loves, or watching my daughter ride her skateboard in front of the house. Thinking back to when my children were babies and I didn't have cancer. I don't even like looking at pictures of myself before my diagnosis, because all I can think is, "I didn't have cancer then". And I wish like hell I could go back in time. That being said, most days I feel positive, healthy, and happy. I have an amazing husband, circle of girlfriends, and wonderful co-workers. My doctors are a wonderful bunch, too. I think PTSD is part of the territory. I wish there was more talk about it, however. Much is written about cancer and depression, but honestly, I think I've had PTSD symptoms as strongly as I've had depressive. Anyway, my long way of saying: you're not alone. I'll say a special prayer for you today. hugs janyce

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2011 07:58PM elmcity69 wrote: hi pattibear, i actually swore by Aquaphor - i am very, very fair and my rad onc was concerned about skin integrity (had 25 treatments). i slathered it on immediately AFTER treatment - actually in the changing room and at night. ruined quite a few tank tops (it was summer), but my skin held up beautifully. it was definitely red and sore by the end, but kept intact. my onc was impressed! i bought the biggest tub i could find, and it was almost done by the time tx was over. good luck. make time for naps later on, b/c the fatigue does build. never had nausea and haven't heard of anyone else, either. keep us posted. hugs j

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2011 09:54PM elmcity69 wrote: Just echoing what many of the gals are saying. Much has been written lately about this exact issue: surgeons rushing to do surgical biopsies when a core needle or other non-surgical biopsy is perfectly appropriate. Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 08:55PM elmcity69 wrote: Hi Fearless One, I am BRCA +, so the issues are different, but I wanted to share about the oophorectomy experience if you wind up going with it. The surgery itself was a snap: in at 10;30a, out at 5pm. It was a laparoscopic procedure: three small slits, very little discomfort - I was doing yoga again in 4 days. kept my uterus since there was no need to take it. The worst side effect is the vaginal drynessÂ  - I mean, whew! Vitamin E suppositoriesÂ are helping, however,Â andÂ  the phrase "use it or lose it" is a good one to remember. Like most husbands, mine is happy to "help practice" to keep thingsÂ up to date - lol. anyway, hope it helpsÂ if you decide to do the oophorectomy, although as other womenÂ have posted, it doesn't seem like an automatic "yes" in your case. Good luck. Â

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 06:12PM elmcity69 wrote: Hi Cat123, Â I'm so sorry you've joined the "pink ribbon mafia", as I've come to call it. There is great support here, lots of prayers and thoughts for you! I did dose dense AC. Sloan Memorial, Dana Farber, and MD Anderson all recommend it - and my onc did as well. Everyone is different, but here are a few of my tips: 1) Drink, drink, drink some more! I became dehydrated between the 2nd and 3rd tx and it really shot me down. Even hot water with lemon and some honey; popsicles; Italian ices; Gatorade; iced tea. find what works and buy it by the CASE.As both oncology nurses kept saying: Worry more about your liquids and less about food. Â  2) Take Sudafed in regular doses. The sinus congestion/pain definitely responds to it. Â 3) Exercise. yes, exercise - I ran/walked on most days, except the horrible ones, and on those, I would just walk slowly around the block for about 20 minutes. The fresh air helped my spirits immensely and the body too. 4) Enlist a loved one to keep an objective "eye" on your spirits. I felt like a wounded animal at times, wanting to isolate. It's okay to need the quiet time, and this is the time to say no to WHATEVER and WHOMEVER you want!If the depression or other mood sx become crippling, talk to the onc about possible medication and therapy referrals. Â Good luck. You can do this. We're here for you. xo
